title: How to Make Filipino Chicken Adobo

steps.headline: Prep the chicken.
steps.description: Wash the chicken in water and drain well. Leave the skin on and bones in.

steps.headline: Mix the ingredients the day before.
steps.description: Ideally, your ingredients will marinate for a day before cooking. Use a large glass or stainless steel bowl and combine the soy sauce, vinegar, garlic, pepper, and tomatoes. Break up the whole tomatoes with your hands in the bowl. Add the chicken and submerge it almost completely in the mixture. Cover lightly and refrigerate for about 18 to 24 hours.

steps.headline: Cook the chicken.
steps.description: Pour the chicken and mixture into a non-stick, 4-quart (3.8 L) pot. Bring to a gentle boil at about 212 degrees F (100 degrees C). Cover and let cook for 25 minutes or until the chicken’s center is 175 degrees F (80 degrees C). Use a meat thermometer to check the chicken’s temperature. Move the chicken to a plate, using tongs.

steps.headline: Reduce the sauce.
steps.description: Skim as much fat as possible from the liquid as it cooks and increase heat. Boil the water down by half.

steps.headline: Brown the chicken.
steps.description: As the sauce reduces, grease a 12-inch (30.5 cm) sauté pan with olive oil. Heat the pan to medium-high or 375 to 450 degrees F (190-230 degrees C). Add the chicken, skin down, to brown for up to 8 minutes. Keep the pieces skin down, but move if necessary to keep the chicken from sticking to the pan. Adjust heat so the chicken doesn’t burn. Internal temperature should be about 175 degrees. Watch for splatter! Cook for up to about 8 minutes or until the chicken is a deep golden brown.

steps.headline: Add onions.
steps.description: When the chicken is a deep brown on one side, turn the pieces and add the onion slices around them. Continue to brown the chicken, and move around the onions to prevent burning.. Cook for 5-7 minutes or until the onions are tender.

steps.headline: Transfer and serve.
steps.description: As soon as the chicken starts falling off the bones and the sauce starts to have a gravy-like consistency, you are ready to serve. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the chicken and onions to your serving bowl. Pour the boiled-down juices over the chicken and onions. Enjoy with white rice. Serve with pinot noir or red zinfandel. For a non-alcoholic option, consider ice tea, lemonade, or ginger beer. Place leftovers in the fridge. It tastes even better after a day or two.

steps.headline: Combine all ingredients in the slow cooker.
steps.description: That includes the rinsed chicken. In this method, all ingredients are cooked at once.

steps.headline: Let sit.
steps.description: Let the ingredients stand at room temperature in the slow cooker for about 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Cover and cook.
steps.description: Remember not to open the slow cooker while cooking. Cook for 3 hours on high or for 6 hours on low until the chicken is done.

steps.headline: Serve with rice.
steps.description: Short grain white rice is most common, but you can use brown rice alternatively for added nutrition. Some people like to add salt to the rice.

steps.headline: Keep the leftovers.
steps.description: Leftovers of Philippine chicken adobe are particularly delicious. Eat leftovers a day or two later, or freeze in a plastic zip bag.
